title: Retirement income review is a lame duck
text:
"That may lead to further adjustments," Senator Cormann said.

Despite a push from Liberal backbenchers, Senator Cormann ruled out the government stopping or slowing the legislated rise in the 9.5 per cent compulsory superannuation guarantee rate to 12 per cent incrementally due between 2021 and 2025.

"The government's policy is to stick to the legislated timetable," Senator Cormann said.

The inquiry's broad terms of reference allow it to potentially explore super tax concessions, means testing for the age pension, income and intergenerational equity and the cost to the federal budget.

But Mr Cormann said the voters had sent a "loud and clear" message to the government that "Australians are concerned about the constant tinkering and changing to superannuation policy settings.

"There have been significant reforms in recent years and the government's judgment is this is a time to let some of these reforms settle and to ensure that Australians can benefit from certainty and stability."

Stocktake of the 'facts'

Former senior Treasury official Mike Callaghan, a former chief of staff to Liberal treasurer Peter Costello, is chairing the review panel.

Advertisement

The Callaghan review has not been asked to make policy recommendations, but rather to give a stocktake of the retirement income system based on "facts".

Scott Morrison won the election partly by campaigning against Labor's so-called "retiree tax" via its planned ban on cash refunds of excess franking credits and catching Bill Shorten out on the Opposition's policy to increase super taxes on high-income earners.

The government has already ruled out touching several parts of the system that could hurt Baby Boomer voters who helped the Coalition win the election, such as including the principal place of residence in the age pension asset test and cutting generous super tax concessions.

Industry experts have pushed for sensitive issues to be probed, such as including the value of a retiree's home in the means test for the age pension and aged care, lifting the qualifying age for the government pension and overhauling superannuation tax breaks for the wealthy.

The government had earlier signalled less contentious kinks in the system could be reviewed, such as the interaction of superannuation and the government pension, which can create perverse spending and investment incentives for middle-income retirees stuck between the two systems.

One former government adviser said Mr Morrison was still wearing the scars from his superannuation reforms as treasurer in 2016, when he took on the Liberal Party's wealthy base and curtailed the generosity of super tax breaks.

He introduced a lifetime cap of $1.6 million for after-tax contributions and reduced the existing annual non-concessional contributions cap to $100,000, from $180,000 per year.

The Australian Financial Review first reported in September the planned retirement income system review was being narrowed to dodge tackling fraught superannuation tax and pension policies that could upset Baby Boomer voters.
description: Mathias Cormann says the review will not trigger any major policy changes because voters are sick of politicians "tinkering" with the super system.
